There are many signs and symptoms of CoVid-19, many of which are common to other illnesses or infections, and some that are more specific to CoVid-19. Some people may be asymptomatic, and won't develop symptoms, but they can still infect others. Symptoms can develop within 2–14 days. 5% of people who do get CoVid-19 will develop symptoms within 2 days of being infected, 50% will develop signs and symptoms within 5 days, and by 14 days, 95% of all people who are infected will have developed signs or symptoms. Here are some of the common signs and symptoms of CoVid-19: Fever, feeling fatigued (very tired), chills (often goes along with the fever), muscle pain, cough (not all people with COVID-19 will develop a cough*), recent loss of ability to taste or smell, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, headache, sore throat. There are also some signs and symptoms that mean the disease is becoming more severe or progressing, and may require someone to seek immediate care. The most common signs of progression of the infection are increased or more severe fevers, an increased difficulty breathing. Anyone experiencing these symptoms should contact a doctor. Patients should IMMEDIATELY seek EMERGENCY CARE if they develop any of these warning signs or symptoms: Bluish lips or face (could mean that they're not getting enough oxygen), increased rate of breathing (breathing faster than normal), feeling shortness of breath with increased rate of breathing, chest pain when breathing (extremely serious symptom and needs medical attention NOW), waking up from sleep feeling shortness of breath (also a very serious symptom requiring immediate medical attention), develop new confusion, or difficult to wake up. All of these are signs that the person is not getting enough oxygen, which is very serious, especially since these symptoms occur within DAYS to even HOURS, in some cases, before going into Acute Respiratory Distress, which leads to the body's organs shutting down due to the lack of oxygen and being unable to sustain fuctionality.
